section_01.section_summary: Rosa Bonheur was born in 1822 to a family of artists, with her father Raymond Bonheur being a painter and her mother Sophie Marquis a musician. The family struggled financially, and Rosa's early life was marked by frequent moves and exposure to art and music. She developed a passion for drawing and painting at a young age and was eventually allowed to work in her father's studio, where she created her first painting, a still life of cherries. Her father's encouragement and her own determination set her on the path to becoming an artist. Rosa's unconventional upbringing, including being raised with her brothers and attending a boys' school, likely influenced her development as a strong-willed and talented artist.

section_02.section_summary: Rosa Bonheur, a determined and talented young artist, spent her early years studying and copying the works of great masters at the Louvre, earning her the nickname "the little hussard." She developed a passion for painting animals and spent countless hours studying their anatomy and behavior, eventually becoming a skilled sculptor as well. Rosa's hard work paid off when her paintings were accepted into the Salon in 1841, and she continued to exhibit her work annually, gaining recognition and praise from critics and the public. Her success grew progressively, and in 1848, she was awarded a first-class medal at the Salon, judged by her peers without academic prejudice. Rosa's personal life also underwent changes during this period, including her father's remarriage and the birth of a half-brother, which led her to move into her own studio and start a new chapter in her life.

section_03.section_summary: Rosa Bonheur was a dedicated artist who continued to study and learn, even after achieving success. She was supported by her friend and collaborator, Nathalie Micas, who helped with her daily life and provided counsel. Bonheur's paintings, such as "Ploughing in the Nivernais" and "The Horse Fair", brought her great recognition and financial success, with "The Horse Fair" being considered one of the greatest works of French painting. The painting had a complex history, being sold and resold several times, eventually ending up in the Metropolitan Museum of Art. After her success, Bonheur moved to a new studio in the Rue d'Assas, which was custom-built to meet her needs.

section_04.section_summary: Rosa Bonheur was a renowned artist with a unique studio and menagerie, featuring a variety of animals that inspired her artwork. Her talent and reputation had spread beyond France, with critics and patrons praising her ability to capture rural life and the labor of the fields. She traveled to England and Scotland, where she was warmly received and found new inspiration for her paintings, including a series of works depicting the Highlands. Rosa Bonheur's success continued to grow, with her work being sought after by English and American collectors, and she was eventually awarded the Chevalier of the Legion of Honour in 1865. She continued to work tirelessly, producing many notable paintings and solidifying her position as a leading artist of her time.

section_05.section_summary: Rosa Bonheur was honored by the Empress with an appointment to the Legion of Honour and was invited to breakfast at Fontainebleau, where she met the Emperor and the Prince Imperial. She later sent several works to the Universal Exposition of 1867, but received a medal of the second class, likely due to the judges' resentment of her long absence from France and her focus on English patrons. Rosa Bonheur had previously run an art school for young girls, which she directed with devotion and intelligence, but eventually resigned in 1860 to focus on her own work. After retiring to her home in By, she devoted herself to her art, producing many notable works, but ceased to exhibit publicly until the year of her death in 1899. During the Franco-Prussian War, Rosa Bonheur showed her patriotic spirit by aiding peasants and distributing donations to relieve their suffering.

section_06.section_summary: Rosa Bonheur, a French artist, refused to accept favors from the Prussians during their occupation, instead submitting to their rule like any other French woman. After the war, she resumed her work, studying and painting wild animals, including lions and panthers, with incredible power and expression. Her artwork from this period is considered some of her best, with pieces like "The Lion Meditating" and "The Lion Roaring" showcasing her skill. Rosa Bonheur's life was marked by both joy and sorrow, including the loss of her dear friend Nathalie Micas, but she continued to work and was eventually awarded the Cross of Officer of the Legion of Honour. She later formed a close friendship with a young American artist, Anna Klumpke, who would become her companion and legacy keeper.

section_07.section_summary: Rosa Bonheur's painting, "The Threshing of the Grain", is a masterpiece that showcases her exceptional talent, taking her 20 years to complete. Even at the age of 77, her talent and skill remained unchanged, as evident in her painting "A Cow and Bull in Auvergne, Cantal Breed", which received unanimous praise. Despite her robust health, she suddenly passed away on May 25, 1899, due to a lung congestion. Her death was met with an outpouring of tributes and regrets from the press and the art world, celebrating her dignity, character, and greatness. She was laid to rest in the Père-Lachaise cemetery, with a large and eminent cortège in attendance, testifying to her well-respected and beloved personality.
